/.title: Hrutvik Patel
/.content:
Welcome to the Home of the garden. This is where I bookmark the tracks I care about most, then branch out into the detailed notes so they can stay focused.

- [[notes/fitness]] – my fitness/workout hub where pull-ups and related experiments live.
- [[notes/next]] – planning and horizon thoughts for what I’m trying next.

/notes/bmo-half-plan.title: BMO Half (May 3 2026)
/notes/bmo-half-plan.content:
[[notes/fitness]]

# BMO Half Marathon plan (May 3 2026)
VDOT is roughly 34 based on the best-effort races (5K 26:03, 10K 62:26, etc.). Wednesday and Saturday remain the only training days, so the plan leans on those two workouts to carry load.

## Pace zones (min/km)
- Easy / Recovery: **6:30‑7:05** (RPE 3‑4) – used for optional midweek recovery walks/slow jogs and Saturday long runs when volume is lower.
- Long run: **6:15‑6:55** (RPE 4, toward the faster side later in the plan). Keep these conversational even if the total is high.
- Tempo / Threshold: **5:05‑5:40** (RPE 7‑8). Start at the slower end (5:35‑5:40) and finish around 5:05‑5:15 closer to race day.
- Intervals / VO₂ max: **4:40‑5:10** (RPE 8.5‑9.5). Shorter workouts lean toward the fast end; longer interval-based sessions may sit near 5:00‑5:10.
- Race pace (Half): **5:40‑5:55** (target race pace predicted from the Runna estimate of 1:59‑2:07).

## Wednesday / Saturday schedule (Weeks 1‑18)

### Week 1 · Dec 29 – Jan 4
- **Total:** 7 km across two workouts.
- **Wednesday (Dec 31):** —.
  - Optional recovery jog 6:40‑7:05.
- **Saturday (Jan 3):** Long run 7 km @6:35‑6:55.
- **Notes:** Single run week; ease into the plan.

### Week 2 · Jan 5 – Jan 11
- **Total:** 12 km.
- **Wednesday (Jan 7):** Intervals 4 km @5:05‑5:25.
  - Cruise or 4×1 km with 1 minute recoveries.
- **Saturday (Jan 10):** Long run 8 km rolling @6:25‑6:45.
- **Notes:** Introduce speed work.

### Week 3 · Jan 12 – Jan 18
- **Total:** 14 km.
- **Wednesday (Jan 14):** Tempo 5 km @5:35‑5:50.
- **Saturday (Jan 17):** Long run 9 km rolling @6:20‑6:40.
- **Notes:** Build aerobic foundation.

### Week 4 · Jan 19 – Jan 25
- **Total:** 10 km.
- **Wednesday (Jan 21):** Tempo 4 km @5:35‑5:50.
- **Saturday (Jan 24):** Long run 6 km @6:35‑6:55.
- **Notes:** Deload week.

### Week 5 · Jan 26 – Feb 1
- **Total:** 16 km.
- **Wednesday (Jan 28):** Hills 6 km effort @5:30‑5:45 on climbs.
- **Saturday (Jan 31):** Long run 10 km rolling @6:20‑6:45.
- **Notes:** Sustained uphill work.

### Week 6 · Feb 2 – Feb 8
- **Total:** 18.5 km.
- **Wednesday (Feb 4):** Tempo 7.5 km @5:25‑5:40.
- **Saturday (Feb 7):** Long run 11 km @6:15‑6:40.
- **Notes:** Gradual load increase.

### Week 7 · Feb 9 – Feb 15
- **Total:** 21 km.
- **Wednesday (Feb 11):** Tempo 9 km @5:20‑5:35.
- **Saturday (Feb 14):** Long run 12 km @6:10‑6:35.
- **Notes:** Sharpening.

### Week 8 · Feb 16 – Feb 22
- **Total:** 13.5 km.
- **Wednesday (Feb 18):** Time Trial 6 km @5:15‑5:30.
- **Saturday (Feb 21):** Long run 7.5 km @6:35‑6:55.
- **Notes:** Recovery week; keep effort easy.

### Week 9 · Feb 23 – Mar 1
- **Total:** 22 km.
- **Wednesday (Feb 25):** Tempo 9 km @5:15‑5:30.
- **Saturday (Feb 28):** Long run 13 km rolling @6:10‑6:35.
- **Notes:** Volume builds again.

### Week 10 · Mar 2 – Mar 8
- **Total:** 23 km.
- **Wednesday (Mar 4):** Tempo 9 km @5:15‑5:25.
- **Saturday (Mar 7):** Long run 14 km @6:05‑6:30.
- **Notes:** Steady effort.

### Week 11 · Mar 9 – Mar 15
- **Total:** 25 km.
- **Wednesday (Mar 11):** Intervals 9 km @4:55‑5:10.
  - 1‑2 km reps with 2‑3 minutes of easy jog recoveries.
- **Saturday (Mar 14):** Long run 16 km rolling @6:05‑6:30.

### Week 12 · Mar 16 – Mar 22
- **Total:** 27 km.
- **Wednesday (Mar 18):** Tempo 9 km @5:10‑5:25.
- **Saturday (Mar 21):** Long run 18 km @6:00‑6:30.
- **Notes:** Largest single long run before the step back.

### Week 13 · Mar 23 – Mar 29
- **Total:** 16 km.
- **Wednesday (Mar 25):** Tempo 6 km @5:15‑5:30.
  - Shortened load.
- **Saturday (Mar 28):** Long run 10 km @6:10‑6:35.
- **Notes:** Recovery week.

### Week 14 · Mar 30 – Apr 5
- **Total:** 28 km.
- **Wednesday (Apr 1):** Hills 8 km @5:10‑5:25 on climbs.
- **Saturday (Apr 4):** Long run 20 km @5:55‑6:25.
- **Notes:** Peak volume; keep effort easy.

### Week 15 · Apr 6 – Apr 12
- **Total:** 27 km.
- **Wednesday (Apr 8):** Tempo 9 km @5:05‑5:20.
- **Saturday (Apr 11):** Long run 18 km rolling @5:55‑6:25.
- **Notes:** Begin taper.

### Week 16 · Apr 13 – Apr 19
- **Total:** 23.5 km.
- **Wednesday (Apr 15):** Tempo 7.5 km @5:05‑5:20.
- **Saturday (Apr 18):** Long run 16 km @6:00‑6:30.
- **Notes:** Maintain sharpness.

### Week 17 · Apr 20 – Apr 26
- **Total:** 18 km.
- **Wednesday (Apr 22):** Intervals 6 km @4:45‑4:55.
  - Short, sharp reps with 2 minutes of easy jog recoveries.
- **Saturday (Apr 25):** Long run 12 km @6:10‑6:40.
- **Notes:** Taper week; stay fresh.

### Week 18 · Apr 27 – May 3
- **Total:** 27.6 km.
- **Wednesday (Apr 29):** Taper intervals 6.5 km @4:45‑5:00.
  - Keep reps short with 2 minutes of easy jog recoveries.
- **Sunday (May 3):** Half marathon 21.1 km @5:40‑5:55 (target 1:59‑2:07).

/notes/fitness.title: Fitness
/notes/fitness.content:
Fitness is my catch-all for anything related to health, strength training, and movement. Whenever I jot down a habit, a workout idea, or a note about recovery, I link it back here so I can quickly find what matters.

- [[notes/bmo-half-plan]]

/notes/next.title: Next
/notes/next.content:
“Next” is where I jot down anything that feels like the step after today’s routine: experiments I want to try, articles I want to revisit, habits that need more teeth.

When something starts to feel like a pattern, it will graduate into its own note, but the ideas live here until then.

<!-- A placeholder link that keeps this note tied back to the Home hub. -->
[[/]]

/notes/pull-ups.title: Pull-ups
/notes/pull-ups.content:
[[notes/fitness]]

I have been trying to get better at pull-ups since personal fitness class in highschool. It's like all exercise-related activities - you pray once again each year that you'll hit your goal of 10 confident pull-ups. Not 3 sets of 10, but just a one time show of 10.

The worst year was 2021, when it was the peak of COVID life and working out was nonexistent. My chest was pulling my shoulders in as I reached for my mouse and keyboard hoping that would change my life. One day I woke up with a knot under my left scapula (shoulder blade). It was by far the worst pain I'd felt - half my back was swollen. I got up, walked 3 steps, then quickly retreated to the bed as I realized I was fainting from the pain shooting up my spine. I'd probably massaged my back too much, and the weak spot sprouted a knot. All that reaching for my machine resulted in imbalanced muscles.

I purchased a pull-up bar that hung on my door. It forced me to do them more often - the most I got to was about 5 honest ones and 3 fart-propelled ones. I was back to no pull-ups again later that year.

The cycle repeated. It was hard to start doing pull-ups since it was hard to see a sense of progress.Doing 3 sets of pull-ups and maybe a sprinkle of negative pull-ups was not helping. The idea of eventually reaching my goal kept me coming back, but it did not keep me consistent. Progress is hard. It doesn't feel rewarding.

Sometimes you don't need to know the end potential. Maybe it's better that way. Let progress lead you there. However, in this case, it's very obvious where progress leads... more pull-ups.

I took a step back recently in Dec 2025. How do I feel good about each week of doing pull-ups? Break progressive overload into such small steps that each step feels rewarding. Along with that, take a video of yourself doing it. This helps you see how you're doing along the way.

What I did:
- Started with 3 sets of 4 reps each.
- The catch is each rep is a negative pullup with a 5 second duration down, holding more at the top half since that tends to be my weaker spot.
- Each week increase just duration by 1 second till you reach 10 seconds.
- Once each rep is 10 second negative move onto increasing reps across all sets by 1.
- Once you reach 3 sets of 10 reps for 10 seconds each. Finally then flip to normal pullups.

This is what it looks like: weeks 1–12 stick to negatives so you can focus on the eccentric control.

| Week | Start Date | Sets × Reps | Duration | Notes |
|------|------------|-------------|----------|-------|
| 1 | Dec 8, 2025 | 3 × 4 | 5s |  |
| 2 | Dec 15, 2025 | 3 × 4 | 6s |  |
| 3 | Dec 22, 2025 | 3 × 4 | 7s |  |
| 4 | Dec 29, 2025 | 3 × 4 | 8s | Feeling more confident, my mind-muscle connection is more obvious through my lats. |
| 5 | Jan 5, 2026 | 3 × 4 | 9s |  |
| 6 | Jan 12, 2026 | 3 × 4 | 10s |  |
| 7 | Jan 19, 2026 | 3 × 5 | 10s |  |
| 8 | Jan 26, 2026 | 3 × 6 | 10s |  |
| 9 | Feb 2, 2026 | 3 × 7 | 10s |  |
|10 | Feb 9, 2026 | 3 × 8 | 10s |  |
|11 | Feb 16, 2026 | 3 × 9 | 10s |  |
|12 | Feb 23, 2026 | 3 × 10 | 10s |  |
